glossary.label: Router Namespace
glossary.text: A file where routing logic can be applied. This file might contain endpoint, groups or middleware declaration. Namespace allows route isolation, which can be useful for having multiple API's with different logic/implemantation. the file must export a default function and the route instance will be supplied as an argument which will be used to declare endpoint, group and routing logics. this will then be passed to the app registry and will be consumed before server boot event.

glossary.label: Router Group
glossary.text: Route group is an endpoint wrapper which applies declared options to the wrapped endpoint, for instance a route prefix, controller, middleware, before and after request events. In case of middleware conflict, route endpoint declaration will be applied.

glossary.label: middleware
glossary.text: array of middleware names, middlewares listed under this group will be implemented across the group endpoints

glossary.label: prefix
glossary.text: value will be prepended to the endpoint path.

glossary.label: controller
glossary.text: controller path must be under (./config/container.ts[ControllerDir]) path declaration. can be shorthanded if '@' is present before the file declaration e.g. : 'posts@PostController' then the route endpoint can be shorthanded as route.post('index', 'index'),  this will translate to (posts/PostController@index)

glossary.label: before
glossary.text: before() ev will be emitted before function/controller execution

glossary.label: after
glossary.text: after() will be emitted before sending a response object to the client

glossary.label: Router Endpoint
glossary.text: Routing endpoint points to a callback function, which can be a Controller Method or a callback function. Endpoints is a part of a Router Namespace or can be a part of a route group. Endpoints also specifies the #HTTPMethod, and can have similar address but must have a different HTTPMethod.

glossary.label: RouterServiceProvider
glossary.text: In RouterServiceProvider file, Routers are registered inside the boot method, which is a ServiceProvider method, that is being executed before the server( @start) event, which is part of chasi's lifecycle. ServiceProvider@boot method is mainly for collecting information, before it runs in the registry. Router instance needs to be invoked inside the boot function

glossary.label: Router configuraion type
glossary.text: router type declaration

glossary.label: name
glossary.text: the value will be used as an index and must be unique.

glossary.label: auth
glossary.text: authentication can be configured from [./config/authentication] please specify a driver that is registered from the auth configuration file or you can set this parameter to false || null, if you intend not to use any auth for your router {String} {Boolean[false]} {null}

glossary.label: prefix
glossary.text: value will be appended to all the routes that will be registered under a router's instance

glossary.label: namespace
glossary.text: a string path to a router container file.

glossary.label: middleware
glossary.text: middleware/s listed under this property will be implemented, to all the routes registered in the instance, except* if the route endpoint/group have a declaration of a middleware excemption

glossary.label: controllerdir
glossary.text: a string path/s that will be added to router's controller path registry.

glossary.label: AuthRouteExceptions?
glossary.text: Option to excempt a route endpoint/s from AuthGuards, all routes that will be excempted in Auth implementations will have no access to the [request.auth] property in <Request>.

glossary.label: data?
glossary.text: router hook, declared data inside this hook will be avilable throughout this Router[Instance] you can access data property via this.$data inside a controller/method or by adding a 3rd argument in a route function

glossary.label: mount?
glossary.text: a router hook where third party modules can be registered/mounted

glossary.label: before?
glossary.text: this function will be invoke before a request is passed into controller/handler function.

glossary.label: after?
glossary.text: this function will be invoked before a request is sent back to the client.

glossary.label: displayLog?
glossary.text: an option to print route information in the terminal.
